etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in John Bingham (fl. c1616). From (i) classical Latin stratēgus general, commander

definitions: (A title for) a commander-in-chief, general, or chief magistrate in ancient Greece, and subsequently in the Roman Empire and the Byzantine Empire.

notes.text: The role of a strategos varied over time and from place to place, and could include both military and political responsibilities, as at classical Athens or in the Achaean confederacy. The title continued in use in Greek-speaking regions of the Roman Empire, and later in the Byzantine Empire, to denote a variety of offices.
